pros: I've been working at HubSpot for nearly 5 years, and came to Australia to set up our Sydney office in July 2014. Over the past two years, I've had the privilege to interview and onboard a high percentage of our current ~45 person team. Each new SydSpotter brings a fresh perspective, and adds to the culture which we are constantly evolving. Having worked in the Dublin & Cambridge offices, I'm lucky to have a benchmark for how Sydney is going comparatively to the other offices. In many ways we operate autonomously as a startup, but with massive support, guidance (and requisite performance expectations) from HQ and our APAC head office in Singapore. HubSpot (globally) is a very special place where I've had the chance to massively develop my career while helping others do the same. Oh, and the product is also amazing/improving everyday.
cons:
1. There simply aren't enough hours in the day to do what we have the potential to achieve in ANZ.

2. We run out of bananas in the kitchen, occasionally.

review_title: Most challenging, most rewarding and most educational job ever
pros:
- by far the smartest people I have ever worked with (and I have worked at companies known for having smart people)
- demanding culture that focuses on achievement and results, not on seniority or face-time
- very work hard / play hard atmosphere with lots of young, smart, energetic folks (and many of them are single and attractive, both men and women - rare for a software company)
- very well known company (especially in Boston) and working at HubSpot for a few years enhances your career greatly
- once in a lifetime opportunity to work for a hyper-growth company with a shot at becoming the 0.01% of companies that go from startup to multi-billions
cons:
- you have to be a "go getter" or "self starter" to be successful, no one spoon feeds you
- compensation is very good, but not top of the charts (this is person specific though)
- people are dedicated and passionate, if your job is not one of your key passions, you'll feel lost

review_title: Flexible working, autonomy and the best quality people you'll meet!
pros: I knew that a large number of software companies offer great perks, but that's not what drew me to HubSpot. Sure the food is great, the unlimited leave gives me the flexibility I want to see my family, the free book program has encouraged me to read more, weekly meditation has reduced my stress levels and the regular team and business-wide events are exciting. But it's the people I work with and the opportunities I have been given that keep me engaged. Someone told me before I started that the people at HubSpot were going to be my really good friends, not only this, they would encourage me to be better, think deeper and bring out the best qualities in me, and this is something I see everyday!
cons:
None that I can think of. I do wonder where I will end-up next (job-wise at HubSpot), as there are limited positions in Sydney, however the office is continually expanding so I expect more positions will become available! 

I understand that transferring overseas is a difficult process.

review_title: Doesn't get better: high impact work, amazing co-workers and work-life flexibility
pros: At any stage of your career, this is a place where you can learn, grow, and have high impact within the company, with our customers, and through the values we live and share, beyond to our communities and across the tech industry. The people here are CARING and SMART- it's a pleasure to come to work each day and know that you will be pushed, and also that you will help push people around you. The work-life flexibility is second to none. There is an expectation you will produce great work, but you have the support and resources to do so, and very high autonomy to do so.
cons: Constant change inevitably causes growing pains, and there is a lot of building the tracks while the train is already moving. You will not sit still and you can expect plenty of trial and error and lots of ambiguity, but this is ultimately not necessarily a bad thing, just not for everyone.

review_title: Great place to work and great culture
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- Culture of transparency is one of the best things about HubSpot. Everyone at every level is transparent about the plans of the business and how decisions are made
- Lots of autonomy to work and bring ideas to the table. People are willing to listen provided you back your ideas with data and logic.
- Company that strives to have a good global mindset. Growing very fast internationally as well
- Great support for internal mobility - there are lots of opportunities for lateral movements internally and HR supports them
- Improving very rapidly in the diversity, inclusion and belonging space. Leadership has this as a top priority and I feel that HubSpot has made great process in the last 12 months.
- Perks are great. A lot of flexibility with unlimited vacation and ability to work remote policies.  This ultimately translates in you doing your best work because you can focus on that instead of counting how many vacation days you have left.
cons: - Salary and total compensation might not be very competitive vs other big tech companies in the area.

pros:
Where do I start?  The people and the culture are amazing.  Before HubSpot I worked at a couple of Fortune 100 companies, did consulting for two years, and briefly owned my own business...none of those work environments came close to what HubSpot has.

Apart from the people and the culture, the training and support is great, the pay is good, the perks are good and always growing (free food, in-house gym, etc.).

As a high growth company career options abound, and lateral moves are common.  I am in sales, and because the sales team in particular is growing fast there is good upward mobility as we add managers to keep pace with the team growth.
cons: In the past I would have said work-life balance, but once I realized I was a borderline workaholic I was able to put limits on how long/hard I would work.  My performance hasn't really declined (I was in the area of small incremental gains where the return for additional hours wasn't there) and I'm very happy with the balance I have struck.

pros:
- Great infrastructure for engineers. You can write code, test it, deploy it and monitor it with great tools and low effort.
- Work on real products. Other big tech companies with Dublin offices do unimportant projects or SRE work in Dublin. A lot of HubSpot's core product is built here and Dublin is not treated as a satellite office.
- Really smart co-workers and a good culture of teaching and learning.
- Lots of team autonomy. The company sets high level goals and it's up to teams how they contribute. 
- Generally pretty low corporate BS
- Flexible for remote work, WFH, etc as long as you are delivering
- Really inspiring engineering leaders and executives who listen and care
cons:
- It has grown very quickly. It feels less tightly knit than it used to.
- Starting to lose the smaller company feel, with rules etc increasing. Although a lot of effort is put into preventing this and keeping us nimble.
- A lot is expected of you. Not necessarily in terms of hours worked, more so your skills and abilities and the effort you put in. It was hard when I started to get up to speed.

job_title: Customer Success Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: HubSpot really is the amazing place it seems to be from the outside.   I have been here for over 3 years now and still love it just as much (if not more) as I hoped I would.   The people here challenge and support me, there is room to make mistakes and try new things, and the work is fun and rewarding.   Yes there is a nap room, and yes there is free beer and yes there is a great new gym but those things are not enough to make me stay at a job for 3 years.  The people and the work keep me smiling everyday I walk through these doors.
cons: We are growing so fast.   We could use some more HubSpotters to help us grow and take the company to the next level.

job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Portsmouth, NH
pros:
I have only been working at HubSpot for four months but I could not be more pleased. It is extremely evident that this company cares about the well being and success of its employees. Yesterday, for instance, I had a customer address me with extremely hurtful and inappropriate language. Shortly after the call, I was contacted by a fellow colleague who assured me that I did absolutely nothing wrong and that she would be following up with the customer to explain to him that he cannot treat HubSpot employees with such disrespect. If you end up deciding to work at HubSpot you will constantly have a team of amazing and talented individuals to stand up for you and guide you to success. 

Other Pros: 
*I am constantly learning new and amazing things about the inbound marketing space. 
*Unlimited Vacation & Sick Days
*AMAZING co-workers
*Room for advancement 
*The negative customer interaction that I chatted about above is extremely rare. I would say 95% of my customer interactions are extremely positive and rewarding.
cons: I have not experienced any cons.

pros: I have been with HubSpot for just under a year and have loved every minute of it. The work I do is engaging and my team and managers have been nothing but supportive. As the company is growing so quickly, there have been a lot of changes in the short amount of time that I have been here but also a chance to take on new projects and grow my skill sets. I see a lot of potential for me to grow with this company.
cons: Not really a con but just a couple things to keep in mind when considering if it is the right fit. HubSpot is growing quickly so that means there is always a lot going on and a lot of new projects could come your way, so you have to be adaptable. Another thing HubSpot values is autonomy. You won't find a micro manager which is great, but if you like to have a lot of feed back and a lot direction on what you should be doing you will want to be clear about that with your manager.

pros:
Very dynamic place. Probably the best managed engineering org I've seen. They've found a balance between process and productivity. Their infrastructure is top notch - you wont have to worry about solving silly infra problems that have been solved  a million times before.  People are nice. I've actually became friends with some of my co-workers, and we still stay in touch.
Their product is great, and customers love it. You actually get to interact with customers as much as you have time for (UX tests, actual dinners with customers, annual conference)
If you haven't so far, at HubSpot you will quickly learn what is actually important when it comes to making software. 
HubSpot is no one trick pony. There is plenty of innovation, new exciting things, and they MOVE FAST!
cons: HubSpot is big on culture and this can be a bit overwhelming. You might feel like you are losing your own identity to it, or that your identity doesn't matter, and it is all about how well you work in the HubSpot system. Whether this is a good thing or not would make for an interesting discussion, but their approach works very well for them.

review_title: A happy place with happy people
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- Great work-life balance, no pressure if you feel like taking a day off or working from home
- Very nice atmosphere around the office, there's everything you need from drinks, facilities & food/snacks
- Open door culture, you can always talk to somebody when you need to
- People are happy and don't complain about work like in many other companies, surely there are faults here and there as in any company but it's not something you come across every day. 
- You can be open and honest even to management without having fear of negative consequences.
- Overall it feels good around here, it's busy and can be hectic from time to time, but it's enjoyable rather than annoying.
cons: It can sometimes take a bit longer to progress in the company, mainly because it's so busy so days fly by, but moving to a different role or department isn't the quickest progression at Hubspot, which might actually be a good thing some times.

job_title: Recruiting Operations Coordinator in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Although I've only been at HubSpot for a short amount of time, it is clear how much the culture permeates throughout the entire company, from team interactions to business decisions (and most importantly, is practiced all the way from the top down)! I have truly never felt like there was a more inclusive, comfortable, and supportive environment to do your best work in. 

I think my favorite part is that all new hires, regardless of their department or title, complete a week-and-a-half of company and product training. It truly bonds your new hire class together and makes sure that everyone is on the same page for why HubSpot works like it does and how they are solving for their mission.

Obviously, all of the other reviews will talk about the benefits, perks, flexibility, etc. The best part is that it's all true and using the flexibility to work remotely or take time as you need it is not only allowed but actively encouraged.

Plus, the People Ops team is amazing!
cons: As of now, I have nothing to say!

review_title: Excellent place to grow and contribute
pros: If you honestly love major challenge, teamwork, innovating, building, working hard and learning a lot everyday- you'll likely thrive at HubSpot. The back of the company sweatshirts read "We Bleed Orange" (orange being the inbound marketing/ HubSpot brand color), and that is a completely serious statement. The team at HubSpot is absolutely dead set on making marketing better and easier, and the positive vibe of that mission is contagious. The HubSpot mission is really clear... and every employee truly has the chance to look at that mission- and help draw the next phases of the road map, which is just so rare. If you have an idea... you share it. If you want to try something, can articulate why it would be a good idea, and have proven yourself to be an A player- you'll probably get a fair shot at it. Seriously. You won't have any dull days.
cons: If the above sounds like more than you are really in the market for... those pros could be cons! Yep- HubSpot is challenging, you'll have serious commitments to your team, you'll be expected to work really hard, and be willing to learn and grow. At the end of the day....  you'll say you really did something.

pros:
1. Lots of good humans here. I especially like the wide variety of life experiences. I hope as we get bigger, we keep taking risks in hiring to bring in more high potential people with atypical backgrounds. 
2. Love my manager.
3. With the growth and breakneck speed of the company, you get so many learning opportunities just by doing your job and keeping up with company communication. I've been able to work on really interesting, high-impact projects, and I'm confident that this will set me up for success in the future, where it's at HubSpot or elsewhere.
cons: Like most workplaces, there are some politics and there are some jerks. There's a fair amount of preaching around how we don't stand for politics and don't hire jerks - this seems a bit silly. They exist. Would love to see us be better at holding people accountable when they poison the well.

job_title: Inbound Sales Representative in Cambridge, MA
pros: great product, people and roadmap for the future.  steady leadership that responds well to criticism and knows when to make changes in order to steward an amazing future for the company as well the individual.  unlimited vacay, good benefits, tons of perks and incentives for sales reps to perform that change all the time to keep it interesting.
cons: very competitive on the sales side because there is a lot of $$ to be made if you can keep up and do well. monthly quotas so you are under the gun each month.  lots of ambitious smart people on the team, so you have to be prepared to push yourself all the time and pick yourself up quickly when you fail.  there is a LOT of expectations and pressure to perform on the sales reps and it can be overwhelming at times but again, tons of information, lots of support from leadership and a best in class product make it much more manageable than perhaps this review is leading you to believe!

pros:
The work environment at HubSpot is like no other I have experienced before or seen since.
The company has a pulse unto it's own, with a constant drive toward success.

In fact the #1 reason to work at HubSpot is to experience first hand an executive team with a near flawless execution of creating one of the fastest growing companies and take it public.

HubSpot was also one of the more transparent companies I have known. Management did a great job of sharing the goals of the company and was extremely successful making sure the employees were aware of what they needed to do to help achieve those goals.
cons:
With a company so driven toward success, it became apparent that the numbers were more important than the people. So in order to succeed at HubSpot you must constantly succeed or live in fear that you will soon be replaced.

So don't even consider working at HubSpot if you arent up for the challenge...

review_title: Amazing company, tremendous opportunity to impact, inspirational leaders, with a lot of heart
pros:
I'm nearly six years into my journey at HubSpot and I couldn't be more excited about the future or prouder of the company we are creating.

Every day we set out to help small and medium sized businesses grow better. We do that by trying our darnedest to create great software that helps them succeed.

And along the way we are creating an remarkable culture that helps every HubSpotter be their best.

We are by no means perfect, but what I love is our willingness to skin our knees and then learn from it.

Shout out to our leaders -- Brian, Dharmesh, and JD -- who really lead by example from the top and allow this culture to thrive.
cons: The pace of change is high.  One of HubSpot's core values is "Move Fast and Iterate".  If you are looking for a slow rate of change, HubSpot is likely not for you.

job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: This is probably the only company that treats you like a human first and an employee second. You never feel looked down upon by anyone higher up than you, you're encouraged to take care of yourself, and even when remote (I am), they encourage getting to know your coworkers! The culture is so inclusive and welcoming and their words match their actions. I was skeptical if a company could really live up to the culture code HubSpot claims and turns out, HubSpot can! They say what they mean and mean what they say. I can from a very bad work environment previously and I have cried on this job with HubSpot but they were all happy tears.
cons: HubSpot is a HUGE product, so I always feel like I am missing some kind of information. While there is a huge database of information available to employees, I still feel like I am often missing key points of information and struggle to find it- such as product plans, pricing, limits, etc.

review_title: Best place to start and grow a career in tech sales!
pros:
Incredible training, an unprecedented amount of transparency in the company, tons of intentional strategies that are put in place to develop the sales team both personally and professionally. Everyone I’ve met so far is very friendly,  helpful, and empathetic.

Being surrounded by super smart people that are all aligned towards the hubspot mission provides a sense of: we’re all apart of something greater than ourselves.
cons:
Diversity is definitely the first thing that comes to mind. There are not a lot of people or color ESPECIALLY in sales. There has been a couple things put in place to make the sales org more inclusive, however, there’s a lot of work that needs to be done. 

A second con would have to be the lack of opportunities to work remote in sales. Most tech companies offer plenty of opportunities to work remote while still developing their career. Unless hubspot is able to come up with more opportunities to work remote, they will lose talent to other tech companies.

pros: After 6+ years at agencies, to say that I was nervous to start at HubSpot was an understatement. I was starting in a new role and in a brand new industry, but after my first day of training, I knew I had made the right decision. The onboarding experience was something I had never encountered before and made my transition comfortable. Beyond product training, thanks to my manager I had my own training and onboarding projects that set me up for success. I continue to learn each and every day at HubSpot and love working for a company that is so transparent, flexible and values each and every employee as individuals embracing their strengths and differences.
cons: It's truly up to each and every manager to set up new hires for success. The L&D team is fantastic with robust product training, but I'm not sure I would have felt so secure in my new role if I hadn't had the specific onboarding projects from my manager afterwards, so I would continue to encourage managers to put the effort into thinking about the best way to train new hires for specific roles to ensure success.

pros: HubSpot Support is a really amazing team. Everyone has eachothers backs and as far as I know there is no backstabbing or nepotism. The perks are amazing and I enjoy coming into work every day and being able to proudly tell others about my place of employment.
cons: The salary. The salary is so low. It is nearly impossible to live in Boston on 35k a year. This is a very technical job and Support Engineers know more about how to use and troubleshoot our product than anyone else in the company, and the salary/level of respect we get does not reflect that.

pros:
- The people. I love my coworkers, they are the best part about working at HubSpot. I learn from my teammates every day and I truly enjoy working with them. The people at HubSpot are incredibly smart, driven and innovative and I feel lucky to work alongside them. 
- The flexibility. I have the freedom to work from home or take days off whenever needed. The unlimited vacation policy isn't unique to HubSpot, but it is a differentiator in the way it is truly embraced. 
- The autonomy. Even as an individual contributor, I own my projects and am involved in all aspects of their strategy and execution. Even though we're a growing company, there is still the startup culture where we all do what we can to improve the parts of the business we control.
cons: - The systems and processes. These are typical growing pains in a scaleup. Maintaining autonomy in a growing business is tricky, especially when several departments rely on the same internal systems.

review_title: Lives up to the glassdoor reviews
job_title: Senior Product Designer in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
Remote working
Great benefits
Comprehensive onboarding
Flexible working
Great Company culture
Honesty as a company - addressing the right issues
Straight talking colleagues and management
The customer experience is recognised as being vital to success, at every level of the org
Company invests in your development and understands that when you grow, the company does too.
My coworkers have been amazing in helping me settle in, giving up their time to meet with me regularly
Autonomy... as a designer with many years experience I was relieved to join HubSpot and find that their commitment to autonomy is a genuine one
cons:
Could do a little more for remote workers in terms of perks/set up, to match other companies out there.
High expectations can be stressful at times
Onboarding can be intense - a lot to learn, lots of people to meet, structure and breadth of the org & software can be confusing and a little intimidating at first.

pros:
Fun and exciting workplace
Surrounded by really smart and talented colleagues in all departments, so your constantly learning and making great connections
Transparency - this is the most transparent company I've ever been a part of. 
Career Growth - the company is growing rapidly and there are lots of opportunities to grow your career
Support - the company is dedicated to making sure that everyone has the tools and support they need to succeed
Flexible work from home policy & vacation policy
Vision - Everyone is on board with the vision and direction of the company so everyone is working towards a common goal
cons:
Would like to see some more benefits around child care and 401k matching. 
There is no defined "career path", so individuals need to take control of their career rather than waiting for something to be given to them.

pros:
Great place to work! The people are the best - very friendly and ready to help you. I work on the consulting side, and I love it. The product itself is incredible and is always being improved and grown.  An awesome place to learn - cannot stress enough how much I have grown in my two years. Oh, also the benefits are amazing!! The culture team is fantastic and always has events and great opportunities. 

Come here if you have HEART!
cons:
It is a big company, and if you are in an international office then you could feel disconnected from HQ in Cambridge.  HubSpot is also always changing, which I like, but I know constant change is not for everyone. There is also a big push for greater diversity, but the company is still not very diverse. I know it is a priority for the leadership team, but the lack of diversity is a con. 

Another con is compensation - salary is less than competitors.

review_title: Great culture and product + amazing career development
job_title: Customer Success Manager in Bogotá, Bogota
pros:
HubSpot has a great culture where we have the autonomy to do the projects we believe in and help the company grow while developing our own career. 

We have a lot of programs dedicated to employee development, which allows us to differentiate ourselves in the market. 

We also have amazing work conditions, having not only great facilities but being able to work from home and in some cases remote – which allows us to do our best work.
cons: Not really a downside, but something that I look forward to seeing on the next few years is a better structure for global hirings and relocation.  As an employee who had to relocate for the job, I felt a little lost at times on this process.

pros:
HubSpot never rests on its laurels and every department is committed to getting better every day.  

You are given a lot of autonomy which is supported by radical transparency in the business.  This allows you to have all the context needed to make the best decisions to solve for the customer.  There are guidelines and playbooks, of course, but you have a lot of discretion in your day-to-day activities.  

In my group, Customer Success Management, we have a great team and the privilege of serving some remarkable customers.  It's amazing to see the impact we have on our customers' success, their lives, and their careers.
cons: As with many scale-ups, we have some high class challenges:  customer counts, a platform that continues to get both wider and deeper, internal systems keeping pace with business growth.  You have to approach this role with a bit of patience and realizing that you will need to be the change and innovation needed to take this role to the next level.

job_title: Software Engineer Coop in Cambridge, MA
pros: HubSpot really puts a lot of effort into having a positive, healthy environment for engineers to work, without going too far over the top. The technology that I get to work with is really modern and innovative, and honestly most importantly I would say is the intrinsic value given to getting things done right. That's not to say that things aren't done hacky and fast to just make them work, but it's acknowledged that this is taking on technical debt that will need to be paid off later. Thought is given to good API design, and there's a goddamn amazing design/UX team. Oh, and the UI library itself is top notch. It makes tasks that used to take weeks or days take hours or minutes.
cons:
All of the backend stuff is written in Java. So if you like Java... 

It is a decently sized company, however well they do of hiding it. There are managers, and managers' managers, and managers' managers' managers... but at least they're all super smart and competent.

pros: Really great environment to learn and grow - and to help others do the same.  The commitment to the purpose of helping customers grow is palpable.  It finds it's way into every conversation and every decision across all functions and levels within the company.  The obvious reason to be committed to this purpose is because it means we at HubSpot will grow too, but it's deeper than that.  There is a strong belief that we are changing the way the world chooses to engage in commerce...and the "we" driving this change is an awesome group of talented, quirky, driven, and giving game-changers.
cons: Having lived in many other company cultures, it's hard to find a con.  Other reviews talk about the pace of change, the high levels of accountability, the expectation that you'll simply need to get great work done fast - these are all challenges certainly, but if that's what you are looking for, you'll find it.

review_title: Fun place to work with plenty of opportunity once you leave
job_title: Senior Support Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros:
HubSpot was a window into a workplace you can actually enjoy. The employees are intelligent and fun. You have access to a snack area, beer fridge, ping pong table, games, hammocks, etc., and you learn a LOT while you're on the job.

Despite the Cons listed below, this is still a really great place to work.
cons:
Into salary is on the lower end of the scale (but by no means is it unlivable or far below average). With enough rear-kissing, you can move up, even if you're not qualified. If you're exceptionally talented, you can move up. 

Once you've worked here, you have the skills to be successful and desirable/attractive to other companies who will gladly hire you and at a hire salary than you made at HubSpot.

pros:
So many. HubSpot as a company is well planned, growing like crazy, and making an awesome impact on the industry. It's also a great place to work! Good perks, unlimited leave being a big one, and a strong culture that makes working there fun. Training was a highlight for me, given I was in an entry level role.

There's a great vibe at HubSpot, and whilst I'm leaving, I would happily come back one day :)
cons: Not all offices are created equal - whilst the company is amazing, it's best to research the kinds of roles available within each office to ensure that there are opportunities you might want to pursue. For example, the Sydney office is amazing; but it doesn't do engineering, or product - so if that's a goal, you might want to consider your options.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer II in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
- I have received world class training after joined HubSpot around the tech stack, the company and will soon lear about the product
- I have seen a lot of investment in continuous integration, push for continuous delivery and a lot of internal libraries and documentation to help us solve problems in such a large scale.
- Interactive new hire training from the Team in Dublin ( who is doing a great job) and making us feel us of something big, making a few days of training seem exciting! Kudos to the new hire team training in Dublin!
- Enjoying all the really smart people I am meeting in many occasions and the whole chill attitude.

Thanks HubSpot, you have made my initial experience amazing! I am not just saying it because I enjoyed the process but the first weeks in this company were amazing! It made me believe in HubSpot's proposition, how it does things and why!
cons: Ownership and decision making within teams means a lot of responsibility, but I'm excited and looking at it at the bright side - not really a con!

review_title: Best company in my 20 year career.. and the best days are still to come
pros: I've worked at five companies in my career and seen many others and HubSpot is, hands down, the best on so many levels. I have been able to work with some of the smartest people I've ever met, been given incredibly challenges to solve, have had a ton of fun, and have been able to help our customers succeed. While HubSpot has already accomplished a lot, the best days are still ahead.
cons: If you are coming in with a lot of experience, come in with an open mind. HubSpot is different from any place I've ever worked at -- and that's a lot of what makes it special. But if you come in unwilling to embrace those differences and always talk about "this is how we did it at my last company", you will struggle.

pros: Talented and lovely people and a very positive atmosphere. HubSpot Berlin is now big enough to be a "serious" employer, with all the stability and some of the perks and amenities you would expect from a large IT employer. At the same time, it is still a dynamic and fast-moving place with lots of cross-functional opportunities and steep expected career trajectories in most roles.
cons:
Right now there is no Human Resources team in Berlin, causing inefficiencies (having to translate and explain German laws and conventions to Dublin-based folks). This situation should improve very soon though as far as I know.

There is no engineering team in Berlin yet, so fewer technical roles and opportunities to liaise with developer teams than in other offices.

review_title: Mostly Great Company to work for
pros:
Smart, helpful and friendly co-workers.
Small teams grant tons of autonomy with very low process/meeting burden.
Great technology platform and platform teams provide massive leverage, so you can concentrate on solving just your business problem rather than figure out many technical problems.
Leadership is good- to-great across the board. Senior leadership especially continue to impress with their level of engagement and transparency.
Has retained much of its small company flexibility while growing steadily.
Steady growth provides lots of opportunities to grow a career.
Great health plan
Solid compensation
cons:
401(k) match is small and hasn't been adjusted in years.
New dental plan has poor network, particularly for remote employees. Currently seems to be disappointing many.
While increase in health insurance deductible responsibility this year from nothing to $500 was small, it makes it much more time consuming to figure out which bills need paying vs having the HRA pay.
Can feel very big some times.

pros:
- Ambitious, hard working, smart people
- Fun company events, department outings
- Free snacks/beer, good health & dental insurance
- Stocks, investment advice through Fidelity
- Good location
- Growing company
- Great vacation policy
- Productive, caring management
- Tuition reimbursement plan
- Culture focused on learning, professional and personal growth, excellence
cons:
Hmm, this is a tough one... In my personal experience there aren't really any downsides. It can be hard to meet and mingle with people outside of your department, but I think that's a challenge at any company that has over a few hundred employees. HubSpot still has a bit of a startup vibe in the sense that it's still growing, there's a high energy level, can be really fun, etc., but it's not a startup anymore, so if that's what you're looking for I suggest you go a lot smaller. 

At the end of the day, there's no other company I'd rather work for. Hands down. Everybody here genuinely cares about our customers, our company, and each other. I feel cheesy saying that, but there you go.

review_title: Best Company I've Ever Worked for So Far!
job_title: Associate Product Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Incredible sense of transparency... 
The company LIVES by the Culture Code... It's not just a marketing stunt.
Everyone has incredible passion and love for the company. They genuinely want to help and do the best they can to make HubSpot's users successful and in turn, make HubSpot successful. 

Team independence is awesome as well. You don't get buried by processes... move fast, ship it and measure!
cons:
A few growing pains... Nothing out of the ordinary but super interesting time to be a part of the company if you're OK with change. 

Salaries can be a bit lower and the benefit packages less than a major corporation... but every company has it's give and take. Salary might be a bit lower but you get a whole lot of culture and excitement in your day-to-day which more than makes up for it in my opinion.

pros: You will work with young people, which is a fantastic source of energy and inspiration. If you are a Millennial, you may feel old, but embrace it. Always free food around, fabulous benefits, gym, amenities, activities, fabulous work environment with all the latest technology and a push for always being better. Plenty of women, plenty of safe spaces.
cons: They have acknowledge their own need for more diversity and are actively working to make the workforce more diverse. I don't feel like it's any different than most places in that respect, but I anticipate in years to come they will be a leader in this too. For this reason, I believe some staff are still learning how to deal with diversity and don't realize when their statements might be alienating to people of color.

review_title: Great place to work if expectations are properly set
job_title: Inbound Marketing Specialist | Account Executive in Cambridge, MA
pros:
People are amazing
Company has a real genuine mission
Desire and actively working towards a game-changing culture
Real-life, actual transparency.  Not 'we're transparent' with no follow-through like many other companies
Fast-paced and changes direction quickly
Any negative is openly discussed and worked to improve
Product works and internal thought-leadership is second-to-none
cons:
Sales compensation and the way commissions are paid are misleading and less than anticipated until reps are very tenured and have sizable install-bases
Quota increases / compensation-decreases the month after the best sales year of all time

review_title: A hands-on MBA in a fast growth (and paced) company
pros:
Smart people, innovative policies and processes, always something new on the horizon.  It's a winning team.  You get to mix it up with many different types of roles (developers collaborating with marketers collaborating with services folks, collaborating with sales reps).

Very strong brand in our industry.  Feels like we're the Apple of marketing software industry.
cons: Everything is fast.  Shifting, changing.  Growing team means growing complexity.  Things slow down, things get lost in translation, departments inadvertantly working at cross ends.  Don't get me wrong, nobody like it when they happens and people always are trying to work things out and work together.  Alignment is a regular vocab word around here.  The micro culture/work/status is not consistent across teams.  But the macro culture is strong.

review_title: Extreme toxicity in a place that claims 'Culture is King'
pros: The seductive elements that are evident at most hip tech companies these days.  Free food, free beer, great benefits, 401k, decent pay, free gym, attractive office space, stand up desks, the works!  You'll feel like a real king for quite some time with all the nice perks.
cons:
This is the 'outstanding' culture that Hubspot prides itself on that I honestly witnessed on a near daily basis:

- Male colleagues who VERY openly talk about which Hubspot girls they wanted to sleep with or thought were hot, in the most vulgar of terms.  If a certain Hubspot female was coming to the office, you'd sure hear about it!  

- Coworkers who VERY openly make fun of and gossip about colleagues on and off their team.  Know that when you are out sick that you WILL be talked about behind your back, and might have a meme or two making fun of you and shared to the whole team.

- A boss, who you are supposed to respect, that gets beyond wasted at nearly every company event.

- Coworkers who talk openly and loudly about topics ranging from the size of their genitals, the girls they slept with that week, the drugs they took that week, and the coworkers (on the same team) that they dislike.

- People who are so genuinely awful that they make the 'no jerks policy' look like a complete joke, but have complete impunity because of their particular relations to the boss.

- Coworkers and bosses who openly start drinking the free beer at 3pm.

- Expletives and extreme vulgarities dropped openly and loudly left and right, regardless of the subject matter, but most often when complaining loudly about coworkers or customers. 

- Bosses and managers that are so inexperienced, incompetent, and juvenile that they not only set the precedent of the above behaviors, but in the face of real professionals waste no time in passing all 'smart people' work off onto them, taking credit for all their ideas and accomplishments without thanks, and running to them desperately for support and counsel in their never ending crisis's.

- Middle-Upper management who know all too well about all the above problems (because they have absolutely been told directly or via TinyPulse) but ignore them by remaining conspicuously absent and silent, or firing the people that have the balls to speak up in more adamant ways.

review_title: Real Change starts from the bottom up
pros: As an individual contributor, you really have a lot of autonomy in the work you do and can make big plays with your team. Orders don't come down from executives -- the teams decide what they want to do and how to do it, start to finish, on their own terms. You of course get direction and insight from people higher up, but engineers, product managers, designers, and business stakeholders all work together in autonomous teams to make things happen. As a software engineer, your work is always high impact, and you get to shape how your team operates.
cons: Especially now, certain parts of the org are feeling some growing pains that come from scaling up. In the long term that's a good thing, but sometimes it can cause some logistical issues in the short term.

review_title: Overall an awesome place to work.
pros:
As you'll hear many of us say, we're never the smartest person in the room. Our colleagues are top notch and the recruiting team does an excellent job at hiring folks who will add to the teams and bring fresh creative ideas into the workplace. I am constantly learning from those around me. 

Great perks and benefits comparable to other tech companies these days.
Flexible schedule and work  from home capability
"Use Good Judgement" policy allows autonomy
Tuition reimbursement offered
Management does a good job of hearing complains and acting on them as soon as possible.
cons:
Sometimes working from home and working on a flexible schedule can get you into hot water with your manager or team. Use good judgement and you will be fine.

If you don't focus, you WILL burnout. We're growing at a rapid rate and it's important to keep up.

review_title: Might as well be one star
pros: Everything you’ve ever heard about hubspot is 100% true. Perks, people, culture is amazing. If you’re in marketing, cx, sales, product, some others your life is amazing. If you’re in BET and you happen to work for a couple of the bad middle managers in areas that aren’t important to Hubspot, then working sucks even if you are surrounded by awesome.
cons:
If you work for a manager who shouldn’t be one and a toxic team member that barely works then it might as well be a 1 star. So they get one star.

There are no growth opportunities in some areas like BET. No where to go unless you career change entirely.

They ignore and brush off any bad news they don’t think is important because ratings don’t like (to them).

review_title: Amazing all around. Great product to sell and terrific company to be apart of.
pros:
-Extremely collaborative environment that always promotes learning and being creative. If you have an idea, you can feel free to share it with your manager, director, executives, etc. 
-Big potential for career growth, if you take advantage of it. I've been in 4 different positions in 4 years, all were promotions to reward hard work. 
-Amazing culture... People like working here, they are friends with their coworkers, benefits are terrific, office space is outstanding and always being improved. 
-The product is world class. It's something you can get behind and that you are proud everyday to sell and support.
-Can only speak for sales but compensation is fair, if not above industry averages.
cons:
-High expectations, which might not be for everyone. It's a demanding (but rewarding) work atmosphere
-East Cambridge is not the easiest to get to, depending on where you live or commute from

review_title: Great environment but can be unrewarding
pros:
- Talented and friendly colleagues.
- Management are very open to hearing your concerns and genuinely try to improve things
- The whole business is very transparent - anything you want to know about how the business works is available to you.
- A good place for talented grads
cons:
- Career progress can be slow, it feels like you get stuck at a level.
- No matter how much they dress it up, you're building marketing automation software and that can be a bit unrewarding.
- Hard to have an impact on a 300+ person engineering org as an engineer
- Experience outside of HubSpot doesn't count once you get in the door - that can make the environment a bit frustrating for experienced engineers.

job_title: Senior Sales Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros:
One of the greatest things about HubSpot is that no matter where you're at in your career the company has something to offer. For those just starting their professional lives there are many opportunities for personal development as well as opportunities to work with the best of the best in the Marketing and Sales world. For workforce veterans there's plenty of chances to get a fresh take on day to day tasks and learn new ways to solve complex problems, especially in the Sales world.

Everyone in the company is accessible. If you're looking for something more it's very easy to reach out and connect, collaborate and work with peers cross department.
cons: Some roles offer less structure and more freedom to work on cross-departmental projects. While other roles offer a stricter day to day and less time for non-role specific pursuits. Not necessarily a con, but something to consider when applying to different positions.

pros:
1. you're surrounded by some of the best talent in the whole industry - tons of opportunities to learn more.
2. there's a real openness to be entrepreneurial, learn more about different functions and to grow your own reputation. HubSpot does everything to help you here.
3. there are endless progression opportunities - moving horizontally or vertically, you'll have loads of opportunities to try new things regardless of your experience.
4. we have free lunches, a gym in the office, free beer and chocolate. You can work from home when you like and the office environment is VERY relaxed (not a suit in sight and more sofas than office chairs).
5. when you work here, you genuinely care about the company.
cons: 1. the company is growing really big at the moment so making a huge impact can sometimes be difficult, but those that put the hours in will achieve this.

pros: The company is growing like crazy and there's lots of opportunity for someone who's highly motivated to advance their career in sales. It's a fun environment, they run contests all the time and over performance is lucrative. Sales mgmt puts on have end of month celebrations at area restaurants/bars when we hit our number and there's budget for  team activities. I started 3 years ago and have been able to more than triple my income in that time. There have also been opportunities to create and add value in ways other than by hitting quota and that's helped me recently transition into a role in sales management.
cons: There's no bench press in the gym...But seriously, It's a high pressure environment where consistent growth and over performance is expected and you will be held accountable. You're held to a monthly number, so if that's off putting to you this probably isn't the right job. Promotions path on the sales side is very numbers driven with little emphasis put on qualitative elements.

pros:
-First and foremost, the people are great to work with and we've achieved this by hiring for HEART. Google the "HubSpot Culture Code" for more info.

-Career growth: We're a growing company and we have many challenges we're looking to solve as we scale, we're dead serious about solving them.

-Product: Our business is strong and our product keeps getting better. We care about our customers first, that leads to great outcomes for our business.

-Facilities: Our offices are designed to make you feel comfortable and happy to be at work, we aim to make HubSpot the best place to do your best work and that extends beyond our facilities.

-D&I: We have ongoing initiatives and resources dedicated to ensuring people feel comfortable to be their whole selves at work. It's a priority for all managers and teams.

There are so many more pros that I can mention, but these stand out for me after being here for almost 3 years.
cons: -It's not an easy job, you are constantly challenged to do better.

job_title: Customer Success Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: When HubSpot says vacation time is unlimited, that they support a healthy work/life balance, and that they are fully leaning into remote work, they mean it! It has been wonderful over my past year here to be able to work with my manager and team to determine how, when, and where I do my best work.
cons: Not that this is completely a bad thing, but HubSpot has extremely high standards for its employees. Meeting those standards is a challenge, which is great for growth and career development, but transitioning to life at HubSpot is an uphill battle. I'm thankful now that I'm on the other side of that, but I wish I better understood those expectations coming in.

review_title: Great learning opportunity, toxic culture/environment. It's a place to develop skills but not a place to build a career.
pros:
-- fast-paced environment
-- decent office location
-- lots of skill building opportunities 
-- cross-departmental training sessions
-- clear performance metrics
-- defined career path
-- peers tend to be pretty friendly
-- accessible alumni network
cons:
-- short term focus (the 'rocket ship' vision is spoken of but not implemented)
-- aggressive growth targets 
-- rampant micro-managing 
-- inconsistent quality/quantity of mentoring opportunities
-- lack of gender diversity on the management team
-- lack of transparency
-- it's just a toxic place to be on a daily basis
-- no vacation policy leads to employees actually taking no vacation

review_title: Looking to grow with a company? Looking to have a positive impact on others? Look no further than HubSpot!
job_title: Management & Leadership Development Facilitator in Cambridge, MA
pros:
It's rare to find a company that has strong values and actually operated to uphold them. Beyond the snacks, coffee garden, flexible work policies, unlimited vacation, career growth opportunities, innovative ideas, and supporting a properly integrated work-life, HubSpot as a tool actually works to help small and medium businesses grow. 

It is rewarding to know that we are enabling individuals to have a better workday, bigger pay check, and aspirational goals through our platform and services. In return, employees are rewarded with a truly remarkable culture and work experience. 

Speaking directly to leaders looking to join HubSpot - come to HubSpot if you want to lead with your authentic style, develop employees for career success not just task success, and have some fun at work.
cons: HubSpot is a place where people are committed. If you are looking to work 37 hours a week, this isn't for you. If you are looking to work slowly, this isn't for you.

review_title: The Best Challenge of My Career
pros: HubSpot is more than a company. It sounds cheesy to say, but I've truly never been pushed as hard, or enjoyed what I was doing, as much as I do here. You will be a small fish in an ocean of amazing employees. That said, the amount of support from employees at all levels of the company is immense. Provided you're inspired by the hard work of others, you will be motivated to accomplish more (and in less time) than you thought possible here. The autonomy granted here, along with the transparency, attention to culture, and paths for career growth are just a few of the factors that make this company amazing.
cons: The work is hard. If you are intimidated by late nights, a fast pace, long hours, or the idea that you may never be the smartest person in the room, then this is not the company for you.

job_title: Business Development Representative in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
I joined HubSpot a few months ago from a larger competitor and I couldn't be more happy with that choice! 

*Great work environment (and office) 
*High level of autonomy
*Dynamic and fast-paced
*Structured and a clear career path
*The company culture is great! 
*High level of engagement from your manager - they really take time to help you to progress professionally. This even applies to managers from other teams - it's easy to reach out and get advice. 
* The people working at HubSpot is amazing and I look forward going to work everyday.
cons:
* The starting salary can be a bit low compared to the competitors, but as soon as you progress this evens out quickly. 
* As HubSpot is growing massively it's important to adjust to the changes and keep up to date with everything that going on! This is not necessarily a con, but I guess it can be for some people.

pros:
The most significant reason to love working at HubSpot are the people.  They hire people who are passionate about what they do and doing it to the best of their ability.  Employees aren't here to collect health insurance and go home - they are here because their work excites them.  

Other pros:
- The office environment has great perks: coffee baristas and cold brew on tap, smoothie baristas, dogs,  free food
- The work itself is interesting and challenging.  Leadership is always trying to innovate our product, GTM, etc, which creates an environment of ongoing change.
- Flexibility.  Working remote, working from home, working at the common space in the building is all encouraged.  Unlimited vacation also help de-stress concerns about work life balance
cons: There is a lot to do, which means sometimes the hours can be long.

pros: HubSpot had a fantastic idea 10yrs ago that changed the marketing landscape. Interestingly the idea has not just changed the marketing landscape, but changed the lives of those involved in the journey. Working for HubSpot is by no means easy, they expect you to go above and beyond to help make their legacy great - but isn't that the point in working in an industry, with great people, selling innovative products where you are truly passionate and fulfilled by the work?
cons: For those that are not looking to elevate their career or unwilling to work hard for big wins, this is not the faint of heart. People here work hard, I mean really hard, and if that's not something you enjoy (despite getting better from it) HubSpot is not the place for you.

review_title: Great company to grow, be challenged and innovate with self-initiative
pros:
- GREAT culture! Culture touches so many parts of the company and it makes it an awesome place to work at.
- There is a lot of freedom to do your best work using good judgement. Decisions are made based on data and you can always try something new provided you make a case for it
- Everyone in the company (including execs and founders) is pretty accessible due to our flat structure. This allows you to meet many people internally and learn from them. No one is "too important" to not grab coffee and chat with you for a few minutes
cons:
- Monetary compensation is a bit below average for tech industry (but we also get a lot of non-monetary perks)
- If you are an external hire new to the company, it may be a bit hard to get adjusted at first because of the unique culture and the "HubSpottiness" flying around.

review_title: Never thought a company this big would care so much about each employee
pros: From the very start of the interview process to this very day. I feel as though management has taken time to plan out a strategy individualised for me to succeed. The amount of money and time Hubspot takes to guide and train each employee is staggering and I would suggest a big reason why so many people love working in Hubspot so much.
cons: Some people will never be happy and can affect the morale around the office every now and then.

review_title: Smart people, tons of learning opportunities, helpful managers, great place to grow a career.
pros: HubSpot is very good at hiring, which means that everyone who works here is smart, talented, and driven (& on top of that, really fun/interesting people to spend time with). There are also a ton of opportunities to learn & grow your career: training sessions, $5k/year to spend toward continuing your education, Toastmasters for public speaking training, etc. I've found that managers here are genuinely interested in helping you grow your career & specifically don't want to pigeon-hole you in the position they hired you for. The philosophy is that if you're good, they'd rather keep you at the company & move you into a position you're happy about rather than see you get frustrated & leave. Also, the flexible working hours/work-from-home policy is awesome.
cons: People work really, really hard here, so the pressure is on pretty much all the time. Very much work hard/play hard. It's not for everyone.

job_title: Customer Success Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros:
There's a reason HubSpot keeps winning best place to work awards. It really is a great place to be. The company truly cares about the wellbeing of their employees and shows that through great benefits and perks, transparency with employees on the direction of the company, and a strong management team. 

There's a culture here where, no matter your role, if you have something to say, your voice will be heard. 

The people working here are consistently whip-smart, super hard working and generally fun to be around. Come for the free candy wall, stay for a great career.

Benefits include:
Tuition reimbursement
Unlimited vacation
Free books
Stocked kitchen
Waffle Wednesday
Dog-Friendly office
Regular team outings
Flexible work culture
And of course, the CANDY WALL! (my favorite)
cons: As we become a bigger company, we're going through the growing pains of a scale up.  On the upside, everyone's aware and making an effort to create simplicity in all processes.

review_title: Quick interview, world class training, & the best company I have ever worked for!
job_title: Business Development Representative in Cambridge, MA
pros:
HubSpot has an amazing culture - everyone is here to work hard, our customers come first and thats how it should be. I am surrounded by former ivy league students, MIT grads, and some of the smartest people I have ever come across. The benefits are great (health insurance, ect...), there is also all sorts of in-office perks, snacks, a gym, coffee, open office environment. The top level execs sit at an open desk just like everyone else - it's incredible. 

When you work at HubSpot you become part of a family of 800+ people and the religion here is Inbound Marketing.
cons: I would say that the only con of working at HubSpot is that because the company has gotten so big it is hard to meet people within the company - but that is hardly a con - you just need to find ways to meet new people. If you're not outgoing this isn't the company for you!

review_title: Best Company to Work for in Boston
job_title: Head of Global Marketing Relations in Boston, MA
pros: You define your own experience. During your time at HubSpot be smart and think about your career 5-10 years down the road. Understand that when they tell you that you can do anything you want, they mean it. Take advantage of that, as HubSpot is connected to almost every amazing company, vertical, job function or opportunity you can think of across the globe. HubSpot is the best company to work for in Boston right now.
cons: Forcing myself to disconnect and have a personal life. My work life balance at HubSpot was fantastic, however, I found myself literally wanting to come back to work because I loved my job and what we were able to accomplishing included the most exciting and rewarding projects of my career to date.

pros: * You can have dogs in the office
cons:
First things first, they tell everyone at the company meetings to go on here and rate 5 stars, take the reviews here with some salt.

* Slightly below market rate pay
* Laughably horrible 401k match
* "We deploy 300 times a day" means "we expect you to get a lot of work done, do all your own QA, and then get paged in the middle of the night when something goes wrong"
* Excessive focus on the stock price
* "We don't care how long you're in the office, only that you get your work done" means spending more time in the office, not less
* Their biggest expense is people, and it shows in ugly ways when they're reducing costs
* Office is cramped and provides no privacy
* Witnessed some unethical, borderline illegal behavior in support and product groups

pros:
Smart smart people
Amazing facilities (thanks for the seperated recycling EVERYWHERE and addition to pre-packed sandwiches and salads for those working late )
Plenty of activities like yoga, cycling, football if thats your thing
Completely transparent, I know whats going on in product, finance and marketing ahead of the curve and I work in sales
The amount I've learned in a year and a half is hard to comprehend
Compensation is what you'd expect from a leading tech company, lots of bonuses and prizes up for grabs too
cons:
We work hard, that may or not be your thing
An always on culture, but a lot of that is self inflicted 
Work remote/from home is on a team by team basis and some get more leeway than others. I know this is something we're working on but flexibility is a serious plus

pros: Great people, intelligent folks get hired here. Folks with a great sense of humor, lots of good schools represented. It looks great on your resume to have HubSpot on it, especially in the Boston area. Marketing is a great area to work in. Software can also be very good. Sales is horrible. Being an IMC is no fun.
cons: Still no women in the leadership team. It is truly a boys club kind of place. Very political place. No Human Resources function. When you leave they write you off and can be nasty about it.

pros: Exponential growth potential and trajectory of our suite of products, culture is hyper customer and employee centric, ton of opportunities to develop as an employee (whether that's our mini MBA program, taking a master class, tuition reimbursement, 1:1 coaching/feedback, moving to a new role internally or via promotion), huge amount of transparency from the top down which establishes trust in our Exec team, and a TON of autonomy and flexibility.
cons: HubSpot is very fast paced and extremely agile, which results in a high level of ambiguity and change. A priority today might change completely by next week, and the more resourceful and flexible you can be, the better. Also, since HubSpot promotes a lot from within, first time managers are common. You'll have to be comfortable articulating how you liked to be managed and offering as much guidance to your new manager as you'd receive from them.

pros: AMAZING. COLLEAGUES. They are some of the smartest people I've ever met, and the most friendly and easy-going. Definitely the kind of people that you'd like to stay in touch and stay friends even after if and when leaving HubSpot. Good job recruiting the brightest people out there!
cons:
A LOT depends on your manager, which can be good and bad. Every manager manages their team differently, and that reflects on the flexibility of where/when/how you work sometimes regardless of how much you deliver.

Also, not much of a con depending on some people, but there is a lack of teamwork in a day-to-day. Of course there are plenty of times when we reach out to others for help/guidance or confirming something, but most of the job is done alone.

review_title: Promising, Fun, Energized Company with Great Culture and Product
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros: HubSpot is an incredible place to work as a software engineer. The team is truly top-notch. While marketing/sales software might not sound like the most exciting thing to an engineer, waking up every day to work on a product that changes people's and company's lives is amazing. There is an underlying trust given to all employees - the only policy is "Use good judgment". Teams are autonomous and have full ownership over their piece of the product. The tech stack is strong and infrastructure is top notch. The office is great, there is energy, and the company is growing. Leadership doesn't get everything right all the time, but they are transparent and introspective.
cons: The company is growing quickly which means there can be a lot of change. Teams are shuffling around often and product can change. It's not a small startup anymore so you won't know everyone.

pros:
When you join a business and go through your training/ onboarding regularly you are fed the cliches around how great the company is. HubSpot is genuinely an environment full of heart, passionate and bright humans and a vision that is so inspiring. Transparency and customer centricity are truly at the center of everything the business does. 
No day is ever the same, change is the norm and even within this fast-paced environment, all Hubspotters are along for the ride. 
Its a place to join if you want to work hard, succeed and be fairly recognized and rewarded.
cons: We have so many acronyms, and for anyone new, there's a lot to take in. We are provided thorough, in-depth training which helps navigate any ambiguity around this.

pros: HubSpot is a special place. Not only can you come here and get to work on cool challenges, helping our company to grow while helping our customers, partners, and their customers to grow, but you are empowered to grow as a professional and an individual as well. You are given flexibility to work how you work best, allowing for non-guilty work-life 'fit'. And you have the autonomy and the resources to successfully accomplish your goals. HubSpotters are smart and work hard, so you're constantly learning from your colleagues. There's a lot of great energy here, and employees like coming to work, creating a supportive, inclusive and positive environment.
cons: HubSpot is growing quickly and has a really strong culture- both great things, but this can be difficult to navigate when you're new. There are a lot of people who have been at HubSpot for a long time with a ton of institutional knowledge and who have deep relationships with one another, and this can be difficult to penetrate.

review_title: Great Culture and Place to Develop
pros:
The management team is very transparent with the employees, sharing all types of financials, guidance, and big bets for the company moving forward.  Lots of autonomy and freedom to manage your role.  Lots of great benefits like stocked kitchen, lunches, beer, admission into road races, ski weekends, mystery dinners, and more.  They invest a lot in their employees to be happy and create an environment where everyone wants to solve for the customer and grow.

The people who work here are all smart in their own way.  Development from your direct peers is something I've really taken advantage as there are so many talented people to tap if you're willing to.
cons: The only area for improvement is having more structured training on an ongoing basis.  I think these are growing pains the company is going through and have made some early tweaks to improve it and still has room to improve.

review_title: I never knew how "meh" my old jobs were until I joined HubSpot
pros:
- The people are some of the brightest I've ever met
- The transparency from top-down is shocking and awesome
- I have never been more excited (or less sad) to wake up on a Monday
- HubSpot is actively working on their culture and their employees
- Free books program is remarkable
- Tuition reimbursement proves that HubSpot really does want the best for employees
cons: It seems like the employees over-emphasizes tenure. "How long have you been at HubSpot" is a common ice-breaker and those who state the longest have an odd sense of bravado. It's even plastered on several display screens around the office. "The pre-IPO days" are reminisced upon as if they were ages ago and those who came afterwards missed out on the good-ol-days.

review_title: The BEST place ever to start your sales career
pros:
HubSpot has done an amazing job at balancing what's important. There's so much autonomy within the organisation, paired with carefully thought-out and rolled-out processes. 

I started as an Inbound Sales Coordinator and am now in a Principal BDR role. The promotion path in sales is incredibly transparent, and hard work is both recognised and rewarded. My managers have challenged me and been incredibly supportive since day 1. 

The people at HubSpot are some of the best you'll ever meet, both incredibly helpful and hard-working. The culture code isn't a PR front to get people in the door — sure, it's a little cheesy, but it really is embedded within the entire org which is so wonderful to be a part of. 

It's hard not to love your job when you work at HubSpot.
cons: There isn't a tonne of opportunity for frequent international travel as a BDR/sales rep here. Only a con if you want to travel for work!

pros:
I'm honestly shocked and amazed how much I love my job and working for HubSpot.
The opportunity to train in the head office in the US was fantastic, you really get sucked into the culture (a word I hate, but it's true). I also made great friends with other HubSpotters
My team genuinely want me to succeed, they want me to do well for my benefit and theirs. 
Completely transparent, it's not just for show
Humility is hugely appreciated and desired in all people - and in turn, everyone you work with is a genuine &nice person. Coming from a marketing/advertising background where people and companies are quite fake HubSpot is a breath of fresh air. 
I actually like coming to work every day
cons: some extra HR info when starting around pay dates etc would be great, this isn't easily found on the company info tool, but this is a teeny critic - literally, the only thing I could think of!

job_title: Head of ECommerce Marketing in Cambridge, MA
pros: The greatest pro is the chance to work with incredibly smart people. When I got here I joked that the people here were smarter and better than me at things I didn't even know I was supposed to be good at. There's zero ambiguity as to how well any given employee is performing because of our very specific performance metrics. There's career flexibility and the company is will to experiment - if you have a role or function you think needs to exist you can propose it. There's lots of access to senior management if you have something to say - and the culture doesn't punish mistakes or questioning the status quo.
cons: Get over the work/life balance thing. The successful people at HubSpot tend to be highly committed and their jobs are always somewhat on their minds. It's part of what makes us so innovative and creative. If you're looking for a job that you leave at the office at 5PM, this probably isn't for you.

pros:
The company focus on helping SMBs grow is motivating. The executive team is inspiring, coworkers are fantastic and the work is challenging. 

Many organizations have mission statements or sets of company values. HubSpot lives the company values from the bottom up and the top down. The management team believes in hiring people with HEART (Humble, Empathetic, Adaptable, Remarkable, Transparent). When you trust the people around you, you let the politics of a typical workplace slide away, and focus on delivering a fantastic customer experience and product.
cons:
The majority of employees are young professionals (which is dynamic and fun), but sometimes lacks years of real-world experience. The executive team has made up for this over time by hiring more experienced managers/directors/VPs. 

Sometimes the focus on 'career growth' seems like if you're not getting your next promotion, you're not growing. This mentality is starting to shift though.

pros:
I've worked at a number of tech companies in Dublin, and have a bunch of connections working at others. HubSpot for me, out performs them all. 

Work
- Great engineering stack
- Very talented workforce
- You can see your changes have an impact very quickly
- Autonomy is very real
- Fantastic perks + salary
- Less meetings, more getting stuff done

Culture
- Transparency is highly regarded and encouraged
- Active social committee across the company, meaning regular events
- Very flexible working hours and working from home
- Free breakfasts and lunches

Office
- Gym on site
- Vibrant modern office space
- Biking area + showers with towels

Career
- Everyone is responsible for their work
- Great opportunities to move to management or continue on the technical road
cons:
Very hard to find problems that aren't addressed quickly. 

We expect a high standard of employee across the board. Some might find this challenging, but it also means you get to work with high achievers.

review_title: World Class Colleagues and Amazing Vision
pros: Great companies start at the top, HubSpot's leadership is remarkably brilliant, driven, and transparent. As employees we are constantly challenged to think outside the box, add value, contribute to the conversation, and go above and beyond goals. No organization is perfect, and there will always be challenges. In fact, there SHOULD be or you're not doing anything right. But what is amazing, is how this company uncovers challenges, understands them, and fixes them remarkably fast. 1 week at HubSpot = 3 months at any other similar size company #GSD
cons: Pace, this is a fast moving environment that can sometimes be overwhelming. It's also nearly impossible to stand out. Our teams are made up of A+ players. Hitting 100% of your goal isn't impressive. Hitting 150% of your goal isn't impressive. But, that's not something that will change and I don't think it's something I'd want to change.

review_title: Amazing Place to Work, and to launch a career!
job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Culture: Everything I read about the HubSpot culture code was accurate. The company does a great job of hiring incredible people and creating an environment where they can thrive. As a new employee I had the opportunity to actively add to the culture here. 




Growth: There is many paths you can take through out the company, and management actively supports you growth. The resources provided allow us to grow with in our role but also earn valuable education/skills that can be transferred anywhere. I started with almost no technical skill but have found a passion for it here and I continue to make progress.
cons: none so far. But a West Coast office would be great!

review_title: One of a kind company in Boston
pros: Real company, real brand, real mission. I believe it when the founders say that they want this company to be an anchor company in Boston that is still going strong in another two or three decades, and I believe they'll pull it off. Great team of very smart people, extremely selective about who they hire. Everyone is devoted to the mission, for the most part everyone has a sense of mutual respect and helpfulness towards each other. You can't work here and not learn a dozen new things every day.
cons: Long hours, high expectations for output. Certain "front line" sales & services positions are tough to succeed in. Some departments and people have an air of superiority, like their work contributes more to the bottom line than everyone else does.

job_title: Senior Sales Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros: The culture here at HubSpot is awesome.  You are empowered to make your own decisions so long as you "use good judgement".  That's phrase that gets thrown around a lot and management means it.  It guides pretty much everything we do here.  It allows us to have fun so long as we all get our work done.  Oh and the work itself is really fun.  I support the sales org and I love the people I work with
cons: We've grown fast so not everything is as organized as I would love it, and there is a lot of work to do on a day to day basis.  There are some small signs of becoming a bigger company (less cross-team collaboration for example) but steps are actively being taken to mitigate these.

review_title: Ideal environment for rapid, challenging personal growth
pros:
- Clear, compelling mission to help small businesses around the world grow and control their own destiny
- "Root for the underdog" mentality
- Results-oriented environment where risk taking is encouraged and rewarded
- Extremely strong peer group
- Terrific customers whose lives we can meaningfully and visibly impact
- Competitive compensation
- Work/life flexibility (may depend on the role, but lots of work-from-home, remote, unconventional work patterns are often fine - unlimited vacation which generally seems to amount to a slightly generous normal vacation allowance)
cons:
- High growth means high pressure
- Tendency to focus on where we are weak/failing which can be exhausting at times
- Depending on the department your job can change meaningfully over the course of even a year (or faster) and it can be hard to get in a groove

pros: I have worked in the software industry for a lot of years, in both startups and corporate. I joined HubSpot less than a year ago in Dublin and I literally pinch myself every day, as to how I got so lucky to join such an amazing company. I know it sounds a little unbelievable but there is no politics and everyone is hugely talented and interested in just doing a good job. In my experience of other corporates - that is not always the case. People are so friendly, supportive and generally fabulous (and fun) to work with. I don't think some of the younger employees, who haven't worked in other companies, realize how good they have it!
cons: The company is focusing on diversity and this needs to continue - we need more grey hairs!

review_title: Challenging and fulfilling work while giving me flexibility to accomodate my growing family
